title: Quiz 8: Industrial & Food Microbiology
description: Test your knowledge on the use of microbes in food production, industrial fermentation, and water treatment processes.

questions.question: What is the difference between food infection and food intoxication?

options.text: Infection is eating the toxin; Intoxication is eating the microbe.
Infection is eating the living microbe; Intoxication is eating the microbial toxin.
Infection is caused by viruses only.

questions.explanation: Infection = ingestion of live bugs. Intoxication = ingestion of pre-formed poisons.

questions.question: In wastewater treatment, the process aims to reduce the ___BLANK___ Oxygen Demand (BOD).
questions.explanation: BOD measures the organic matter available for biological breakdown.

questions.question: Which of the following are industrial products of microorganisms? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Microbes produce all of these in industrial settings.

questions.question: Match the fermentation metabolite type with its characteristic:

pairs.right: Produced during active growth (e.g., amino acids)

questions.explanation: Primary = needed for growth. Secondary = produced when growth slows.

questions.question: What is the term for any desirable change to a food or beverage that occurs as a result of microbial growth?
questions.explanation: Fermentation transforms food (e.g., milk to yogurt, grapes to wine).

questions.question: Starter cultures in food production ensure consistent fermentations.
questions.explanation: Using known starter cultures provides predictable results compared to spontaneous fermentation.

questions.question: Which organism is commonly associated with food intoxication?
questions.explanation: S. aureus produces toxins in food that cause rapid illness.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a 'Bioreporter'?

options.text: To signal presence of contaminants using innate capabilities

questions.explanation: Bioreporters use microbial signaling to detect environmental factors.

questions.question: Secondary metabolites are essential for the immediate survival and reproduction of the microbe.
questions.explanation: Primary metabolites are essential; secondary ones are not immediately needed.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common foodborne virus?
questions.explanation: Hepatitis A is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, often through food.
